abstractText: In this paper, the bit error rate (BER) performance of underwater wireless optical communication (UWOC) systems with on-off keying (OOK) modulation and an avalanche photodiode (APD) detector are analyzed in a wide range of oceanic turbulence environment, such as lognormal, Gamma, K,Weibull, and ExponentiatedWeibull distributions. To achieving this goal, a newmathematical systemmodel is established, which has not only considered the aggregated degrading phenomena, namely the absorption, scattering, and turbulence, but also been suitable for describing UWOC with APD receiver. Then the closed-form expressions of the BER performances of UWOC with APD for different turbulence distributions are derived in detail by subdividing the working situation into high and lower inter-symbol interference (ISI) scenarios. Theoretical analysis and computer simulations show that no matter what the ISI levels are, the derived closed-form expressions for system BER under various turbulences can approximate the accurate integral ones well. This is obviously helpful to the design and performance evaluation of UWOC systems. INDEX TERMS BER performance, UWOC, APD receiver, oceanic turbulence, statistical distribution.

I. INTRODUCTION In recent years, underwater wireless optical communication (UWOC) has attracted many researchers because of its high data rate, low latency, and solid reliability compared with other traditional underwater counterparts [1], [2]. Similar to the transmission in a free space optical (FSO) communication, the received signal in UWOC also suffers severe aggregated degrading phenomena, namely absorption, scattering, and turbulence, which will inevitably cause channel loss and time dispersion, and thus degrade the system performance. Usually, a simple and efficient method called Monte Carlo (MC) simulation has been proposed to investigate the fading-free impulse response (FFIR) induced by the absorption and scattering [3], [4]. While as to the turbulence, a probability statistical model is generally adopted to characterize the channel fading caused by oceanic turbulence based on a series of laboratory experiment measurements [5]–[8].
So far, based on the turbulence distributions disclosed above, many studies have been focused on the performance analyses of the UWOC with intensity modulation and PIN (Positive Intrinsic-Negative) detector. For example, in [9],

a simple PIN receiver model was adopted to evaluate both the average bit error rate (BER) and outage probability of UWOC in awide range of optical turbulence. However, in this literature, the authors only provided Gaussian quadrature approximations to the BER integral expressions derived under various turbulence distributions, nor they considered the more complicated avalanche photodiode (APD) receiver. In [10], a complicated Exponential-Generalized Gamma (EGG) distribution model was proposed to depict the mixing air bubbles and temperature gradient channel. Based on this modelling, the authors investigated the closed-form expressions for the outage, average BER, and ergodic capacity of several modulation schemes under an additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel plus pure absorption/scattering path loss effects neglecting inter-symbol interference (ISI). In [11], a vertical underwater visible light communication link degraded by cascaded Gamma-Gamma turbulence fading and pointing error was studied, and the associated closed-form formula for M -ary pulse amplitude modulation (PAM) was also derived. In [12], a differential phase-shift-keying (DPSK) modulated underwater wireless optical communication systems with an aperture receiver was presented. Based on Gamma-Gamma channel model, the analytical expressions for mean BER of UWOC over moderate to strong oceanic turbulence were derived by the help

of the Whittaker function. Similarly as the receiver model mentioned in [9], PIN photodiodes were assumed to be the standard receivers in these cited work. Then [13] analytically studied the performance of multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) underwater wireless optical communication systems with on-off keying (OOK), and obtained the exact and upper bound BER expressions for both the optimal and equal gain combinings. Although the so-called photon-counting approach was applied in [13] to evaluate the system’s BER of single-input single-output (SISO) in the presence of signal-dependent shot noise, the Poisson distribution modeling to the shot noise and the receiver output moment generating function (MGF) complicated the whole system’s analysis and corresponding computer simulations. Besides the above, [14], [15] also considered the APD receiver situations and analyzed the related BER performances of pulse position modulation (PPM) in an atmospheric turbulence environment. However, no further consideration was given in [14] to derive a closed-form formula for the studied system, and only upper bounds were deduced. While in [15], the authors used the Poisson point process to establish the receiving signal model and neglected the ISI caused by channel time dispersion, and moreover, only Gaussian numerical integration formulas were designed to compute the final results. Recently, base on the previous work in [15] and [16] extended the BER analysis of PPM to a strong Gamma-Gamma turbulence fading environment, and provided by computer simulations the BER variations versus the average APD gain, modulation order, as well as various turbulence parameters. Since APD receiver can greatly outperform the traditional PIN one due to its intrinsic average gain [17], people prefers to use APD instead of PIN to mitigate the channel loss and then to enhance the system transmission length in seawater [18]. Despite this, however, the signal model of APD is hard to be analyzed because an excessive shot noise term relating to the input signal is introduced besides the thermal noise, and this inevitably complicates the performance analysis of UWOC. In this paper, based on the research activities about the BER analyses of UWOC with PIN under various turbulence distributions in [9], and on the shot noise term construction of APD explained in [17], we decide to extend the BER performance analyses of UWOC in [9] to a more general APD receiver scenario based on a new mathematical system model. Note that this model will consider the aggregated channel attenuation consisting of channel loss, time dispersion, and turbulenceinduced fading, and more importantly, the input-dependent shot noise besides the traditional thermal noise. We will also try our best to derive the closed-form formulas of BERs of UWOC with OOK modulation under a wide range of turbulence distributions according to our identification to the ISI.
In this paper, our main contributions are summarized and listed as follows:
1) Different from the past studies, we propose a new mathematical system model to analyze the OOK BER performance of UWOC with APD receiver in a wide range of optical turbulence for the first time. Compared with the work in [13] and [15], we induce an additional input-dependent shot noise term in the received signal expression to represent the effect of APD based on the exhaustive experiments and simulation work reported in [17]. 2) An optimal decision threshold for OOK intensity modulation, which results in a minimal system BER, is provided. Based on this threshold, the instantaneous BER conditioned on aggregated fading and previously transmitted OOK symbols and its associated average BER over a general turbulence distribution are derived. Compared with the ones given in [9] and [13], the numerator terms in theQ-function argument representing the probabilities of error are unrelated to the ISI. This will obviously simplify the final BER analyses and simulations. 3) Closed-form formulas for the average system BER are derived according to different ISI identification. That is, in the high ISI scenario, due to the complicated matched filtering output of the received signal for APD, only classic gaussian quadrature or simplified trapezoidal methods could be utilized to approximate the accurate BER integration expressions. While in the case of a lower ISI, closed-form expressions for the average BER are derived through the higher transcendental Meijer-G function after some skillful manipulations to the original integrands and after necessary approximation except the special lognormal distribution. In contrast, however, only gaussian quadrature approximations were provided in [9] and [13]–[15] to evaluate the average BER performance of UWOC systems.
The rest of this paper is organized as follows: Section II overviews the UWOC channel modeling and thoroughly explains our newly proposed mathematical system model for OOK modulation and APD receiver; In Section III, we describe the commonly considered statistical distributions for underwater communications and clarify how their constant parameters can be obtained; In Section IV, we derive the closed-form average BER formulas for UWOC system with APD receiver under various turbulence distributions by considering different ISI situations; In Section V, computer simulations are provided to verify our theoretical derivations and analyses; Finally, in Section VI, some conclusions are made to end the paper.
II. CHANNEL AND SYSTEM MODEL A. CHANNEL MODELING IN UWOC Propagation of light beam in underwater medium results in interactions of photons with various seawater particles either

in the form of absorption or scattering [19]. It is worth noting that while absorption only appears as a loss to the received optical power, the scattering is a more complex procedure which contributes to both temporal spread and attenuation of the received intensity since some of the scattered photonsmay deviate from the propagation path and not reach the receiver. The total energy loss due to the absorption and scattering can be characterized by extinction coefficient c(λ) = a(λ)+b(λ), where a(λ) and b(λ) represent the absorption coefficient and scattering coefficient respectively, and λ is the wavelength of light wave. Obviously, these coefficients vary with the light source wavelength, and it has been shown in [19] that the absorption and scattering have their minimum effects at the wavelength interval 400 nm<λ<530 nm. Hence, UWOC system employs the blue/green region of the visible light spectrum to implement data communication.
Based on the elaborate researches carried out in [3], [4], and [20] on the channel modeling of UWOC and related comprehensive Monte Carlo (MC) simulations therein, the channel loss of UWOC caused by both absorption and scattering can be simply modeled as the so-called fading free impulse response (FFIR). In particular, the large amount of multiple scattering, depending on the water type, divergence of source beam, and field of view (FoV) of the receiver, considerably spreads the received light intensity in the temporal domain such that, for the required high data transmission rate on the order of Mbps or Gbps, the delay spread of the channel is comparable with or even larger than the transmitted bit duration, leading to a severe inter-symbol interference (ISI). For the sake of generality and accuracy, in this paper, in order to appropriately include the absorption and scattering effects, we simulate the UWOC channel based on the MC method in a similar way to [3], [4], and denote the FFIR results with h0(t) throughout our analysis. Besides the FFIR depicted above, the oceanic turbulence, which occurs as a result of random variations of the refractive index due to fluctuations of water temperature and salinity [21], is another important factor affecting the channel quality. In order to take into account the turbulence-induced fading effects as well, we multiply the FFIR of the channel
by a positive multiplicative fading coefficient hF in a similar approach to that in [9], [13], and [24]. Depending on the experimental studies in [5], [7], and [8], the probability density function (PDF) for possible oceanic turbulence, from weak to strong, can vary in a wide range of scope, which will be discussed in section III. Moreover, extensive research activities have been carried out in the past few years on the theoretical characterization of turbulence strength under water, measured by scintillation index, and relating this metric to the physical properties and turbulence parameters of the UWOC channel [22], [23]. The scintillation index of a light wave in UWOC with instantaneous intensity I = I0hF is defined as [20]
σ 2I = E[I2]− E2[I ] E2[I ] = E[h2F ]− E 2[hF ] E2[hF ] , (1)
where I0 is the fading-free intensity, hF is the multiplicative turbulence fading coefficient, and E(x) denotes the expectation value of the random variable x. Scintillation index is usually referred to as a threshold for separating the weak and strong turbulence regimes, i.e., when this parameter is smaller than unity, the channel is defined as weak turbulence, and vice versa [9].

V. NUMERICAL RESULTS In this section, we shall provide some numerical results for the average BER of UWOC systems with OOK modulation and APD receiver under a wide range of oceanic turbulence characterized by various distributions discussed above. In order to keep the simulation results as accurate as possible, we consider coastal and turbid harbor water links with related typical set of absorption and scattering coefficients of (a, b) = (0.179, 0.219) and (0.336, 1.824)m−1 respectively [19]. Then we apply the same procedures as that in [3] and [4] and use the identically typical system parameters to simulate the channel FFIR for both laser-based collimated and LED-based diffusive links. Some of the important parameters used for the FFIR and BER simulations are listed in Table 2. Please note that a green light source with wavelength of 532nm is assumed because the blue/green region of visible light generally suffers the lowest attenuation in natural seawater according to many field tests [3], [4], [19]. Moreover, although APD receiver’s bandwidth is mostly governed by the amplifier’s gain bandwidth product (GBP) and APD’s rise time, for the purpose of simplicity of calculation and simulation, a general larger bandwidth, that is 5GHz, is selected as the filter’s bandwidth to support the simulated high data rates in this paper.
Besides, considering that the value of the aperture diameter will affect the simulation results (also known as the aperture averaging effect in [12]), we also compare the effects of aperture size D0 of 15cm and 20cm on the BER performance of UWOC systems. Figs. 1 and 2 demonstrate the temporal-domain FFIRs of a 6m LED-based diffusive UWOC link in turbid harbor waters and a 25m laserbased collimated UWOC link in coastal waters under different receiver aperture diameter situations. Comparing these two figures shows that increasing the aperture diameter will enlarge the quantized intensity obviously. And the LED-based transmission also significantly increases the

channel diffusivity and therefore enlarges the channel loss and temporal dispersion. Defining the time delay spread of FFIR as Td , it is not difficult to find that, for the case of 6m LED-based diffusive UWOC link, the delay spreads associated with the aperture size ofD0 = 20cm and 15 cm are Td = 4.1ns and 3.8 ns respectively. And in the case of 25m laser-based diffusive link, we have Td = 0.125ns and 0.1 ns for the two aperture sizes respectively. As a consequence, the 6m LED-based turbid harbor link has a much worse channel quality than the 25m laser-based coastal one.
In order to compare the impacts of different aperture diameter on the system performance, Figs. 3 and 4 depict the average BERs versus average transmitted power per bit when the APD receiver adopts different aperture size D0 in the 6m LED-based turbid harbor water link and the 25m laser-based coastal water link respectively. From the results, the average BERs of the UWOC systems when D0 = 20cm are always better than that when D0 = 15cm for different considered distributions, turbulence strength, and transmission data rate. This is obvious due to the so-called aperture averaging effect [12], since the more larger is the receiver aperture, the more received transmitting photons. Unless otherwise mentioned, in the following sections, we shall choose D0 = 20cm as the receiver aperture diameter to finish our system BER performance simulations.

VI. CONCLUSION In this paper, a new mathematical system model for APD receiver, which has induced an input-dependent shot noise term, is established to analyze the BER performance of UWOC systems in a wide range of optical turbulence, such as Lognormal, K, Gamma, Weibull and EW distributions. Two working scenarios, that is, the high and lower ISI cases, are separated to derive the related closed-form BER expressions respectively. Due to the complicated matched filtering output of the received signal for APD, only the classic Gaussian quadrature or simplified trapezoidal methods could be used to approximate the accurate BER integration expressions in the case of high ISI. Whereas, in the lower ISI condition, the closed-form expressions for average BERs can almost be derived by the help of the higher transcendental Meijer-G function and further verified by computer simulations under the considered distributions after some necessary simplification and manipulations. Various simulations are also supplied and then analyzed to show the performance gaps among different turbulence distributions when scintillation index is changed.
